body:
Thanks for the super nice report.

Bisected to 6e38a56f4c399551c3fe3d399bddfa8083ccd0f1 - this is very likely caused by eager task execution as well.

The problem is here:

https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy/blob/13f42105fd29c0a5dc1889803bac2cc1a460d63d/mitmproxy/proxy/server.py#L147-L153

The handler is now processing events before we reach `server_event(events.Start())`. We probably shouldn't just reorder those statements as this would cause `.handler` to be unset when `server_event` is called initially. We should figure out if we can explicitly spawn tasks lazily here. :)

repository.name: mitmproxy
repository.description: An interactive TLS-capable intercepting HTTP proxy for penetration testers and software developers.

body: @mhils continuation from Discord: were you able to reproduce this locally? I can't repro this with 10.2.4 when launching from the venv, only with the downloaded binary. I don't understand why that would make a difference. I'd need to repro it in order to properly evaluate the stderr flushing situation.

@Prinzhorn: You can get precompiled binaries for branches from https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy/actions/workflows/main.yml. Does that help?

Feel free to create branches to evaluate things.
I mean it might somewhat help, but I'm just confused as to why I can't trigger the async `client_connected` bug locally. I need to look into this again next week.

1. `git clone git@github.com:mitmproxy/mitmproxy.git`
2. `cd mitmproxy`
3. `git checkout bc3367cce6d45f18348f33b5025ba2bc65362610` (one before https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy/commit/d4200a7c0d2f4efd77c44651645b59662a29a54a)
4. `python3 -m venv venv`
5. `venv/bin/pip install -e ".[dev]"`
6. `source venv/bin/activate`
7. `mitmdump --scripts addon.py` (addon from above)
8. `curl --insecure --proxy localhost:8080 https://example.com/`

@mhils can you explain why the above _works_ (no `AssertionError`)? But downloading a build from before the fix (https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy/actions/runs/8366491404) does not?

I'm on Ubuntu 23.10

```
$ python3 --version
Python 3.11.6
```
Fundamentally this is a race condition, so I'm not surprised that it works in some environment but not in others. For example, the Python version is different. :)
I was not aware that it's a race condition, it does indeed repro consistently with Python 3.12. So now i can finally look into the stderr flushing thing ;)
